p: Preserving and transmitting the intangible aspects of social life often depend upon conserving the tangible–including natural, built, and historic environments. The devastating 2011 earthquake and tsunami in the northeast region of Japan prompted renewed interest in the lessons of tsunami memorials or “tsunami stones,” markers placed at elevations above the devastating flooding from previous tsunamis. For Itoko Kitahara, a specialist in the history of environmental disasters, “‘tsunami stones are warnings across generations, telling descendants to avoid the same suffering of their ancestors’” (quoted in Fackler, 2011; see also Suppasri et al., 2013).
